sn18.12-20:0.3.eng: The Nine Discourses on Sights, Etc.

sn18.12-20:9.8.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn18.2:1.11.pli: “evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpesupi nibbindati … saddesupi nibbindati … gandhesupi nibbindati … rasesupi nibbindati … phoṭṭhabbesupi nibbindati … dhammesupi nibbindati;
sn18.2:1.11.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

sn18.21:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn18.21:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn18.21:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti?
sn18.21:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs?”
sn18.21:1.3.comm: “I-making” (ahaṅkāra) emphasizes the active role of the mind in creating a sense of self through its thoughts, habits, and desires. This is in contrast with the English notion of “ego”, which presents self as a given construct. | “Mine-making” (mamaṅkāra) is the propensity of the mind to appropriate things as possessions. | “Conscious body” (saviññāṇake kāye) echoes Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.2, where the dying man descends into a new life being “one with consciousness” (savijñano bhavati). |  “All signs” (sabbanimitta) are the “features” (also nimitta) that characterize sensory stimulation (eg. MN 112:15.1).

sn18.21:1.4.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, rāhula, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn18.21:1.4.eng: “Rāhula, one truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn18.21:1.5.eng: One truly sees any kind of feeling …

sn18.21:1.8.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn18.21:1.8.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn18.21:1.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, rāhula, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti.
sn18.21:1.9.eng: That’s how to know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs.”

sn18.22:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn18.22:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn18.22:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato imasmiṃ ca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhā samatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttan”ti?
sn18.22:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the heart is rid of I-making, mine-making, and conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs; and going beyond discrimination, it’s peaceful and well freed?”
sn18.22:1.3.comm: Three kinds of discrimination, all based in conceit:  “I’m better”, “I’m equal”, “I’m worse”.(SN 45.162).

sn18.22:1.4.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, rāhula, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimutto hoti.
sn18.22:1.4.eng: “Rāhula, when one truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self,’ one is freed by not grasping.

sn18.22:2.1.eng: When one truly sees any kind of feeling …

sn18.22:2.4.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimutto hoti.
sn18.22:2.4.eng: When one truly sees any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self,’ one is freed by not grasping.

sn18.22:2.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, rāhula, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhā samatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttan”ti.
sn18.22:2.5.eng: That’s how to know and see so that the heart is rid of I-making, mine-making, and conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs; and going beyond discrimination, it’s peaceful and well freed.”

sn18.22:3.7.eng: The Linked Discourses with Rāhula are complete.

sn18.3:1.3.eng: Is eye consciousness permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.3:1.9.eng: Is mind consciousness permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.3:1.11.pli: “evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhuviññāṇasmimpi nibbindati …pe… sotaviññāṇasmimpi nibbindati … ghānaviññāṇasmimpi nibbindati … jivhāviññāṇasmimpi nibbindati … kāyaviññāṇasmimpi nibbindati … manoviññāṇasmimpi nibbindati;
sn18.3:1.11.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with eye consciousness, ear consciousness, nose consciousness, tongue consciousness, body consciousness, and mind consciousness.

sn18.4:1.3.eng: Is eye contact permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.4:1.9.eng: Is mind contact permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.4:1.11.pli: “evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusamphassasmimpi nibbindati …pe… sotasamphassasmimpi nibbindati … ghānasamphassasmimpi nibbindati … jivhāsamphassasmimpi nibbindati … kāyasamphassasmimpi nibbindati … manosamphassasmimpi nibbindati;
sn18.4:1.11.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with eye contact, ear contact, nose contact, tongue contact, body contact, and mind contact.

sn18.5:1.3.pli: cakkhusamphassajā vedanā niccā vā aniccā vā”ti?
sn18.5:1.3.eng: Is feeling born of eye contact permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.5:1.9.pli: manosamphassajā vedanā niccā vā aniccā vā”ti?
sn18.5:1.9.eng: Is feeling born of mind contact permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.5:1.11.pli: “evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusamphassajāya vedanāyapi nibbindati …pe… sota … ghāna … jivhā … kāya … manosamphassajāya vedanāyapi nibbindati …pe…
sn18.5:1.11.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with feeling born of eye contact, ear contact, nose contact, tongue contact, body contact, and mind contact. …”

sn18.6:1.3.eng: Is perception of sights permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.6:1.9.eng: Is perception of ideas permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.6:1.11.pli: “evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasaññāyapi nibbindati …pe… saddasaññāyapi nibbindati … gandhasaññāyapi nibbindati … rasasaññāyapi nibbindati … phoṭṭhabbasaññāyapi nibbindati … dhammasaññāyapi nibbindati …pe…
sn18.6:1.11.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the perception of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas. …”

sn18.7:1.3.eng: Is intention regarding sights permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.7:1.9.eng: Is intention regarding ideas permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.7:1.11.pli: “evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasañcetanāyapi nibbindati …pe… saddasañcetanāyapi nibbindati … gandhasañcetanāyapi nibbindati … rasasañcetanāyapi nibbindati … phoṭṭhabbasañcetanāyapi nibbindati … dhammasañcetanāyapi nibbindati …pe…
sn18.7:1.11.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with intention regarding sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas. …”

sn18.8:1.3.eng: Is craving for sights permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.8:1.9.eng: Is craving for ideas permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.8:1.11.pli: “evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpataṇhāyapi nibbindati …pe… saddataṇhāyapi nibbindati … gandhataṇhāyapi nibbindati … rasataṇhāyapi nibbindati … phoṭṭhabbataṇhāyapi nibbindati … dhammataṇhāyapi nibbindati …pe…
sn18.8:1.11.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas. …”

sn18.9:1.3.eng: Is the earth element permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.9:1.9.eng: Is the consciousness element permanent or impermanent?”

sn18.9:1.11.pli: “evaṃ passaṃ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako pathavīdhātuyāpi nibbindati …pe… āpodhātuyāpi nibbindati … tejodhātuyāpi nibbindati … vāyodhātuyāpi nibbindati … ākāsadhātuyāpi nibbindati … viññāṇadhātuyāpi nibbindati …pe…
sn18.9:1.11.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the earth element, water element, fire element, air element, space element, and consciousness element …”

sn19.1:1.1.comm: In this collection, a monk with psychic power sees beings invisible to the normal eye who are suffering due to their bad deeds in past lives. The Buddha confirms the vision, and explains the reason why they are experiencing that particular form of suffering. In each case the punishment fits the crime, although it is not always obvious how, so I note the connections.

sn19.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn19.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn19.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ca lakkhaṇo āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno gijjhakūṭe pabbate viharanti.
sn19.1:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Mark and Venerable Mahāmoggallāna were staying on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
sn19.1:1.3.comm: Lakkhaṇa (“Mark”) appears only here and in the corresponding passage at Bu Pj 4:9.1.1. He sees the “marks” by which the results of deeds are manifest, a topic elsewhere treated under the “marks” of a Great Man (DN 30). I translate the name to emphasize its artifice.

sn19.1:1.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yenāyasmā lakkhaṇo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ etadavoca:
sn19.1:1.4.eng: Then Mahāmoggallāna robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Mark and said to him,

sn19.1:1.5.eng: “Come, Reverend Mark, let’s enter Rājagaha for alms.”

sn19.1:1.6.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā lakkhaṇo āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa paccassosi.

sn19.1:1.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto aññatarasmiṃ padese sitaṃ pātvākāsi.
sn19.1:1.7.eng: As Mahāmoggallāna was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain he smiled at a certain spot.

sn19.1:1.8.pli: Atha kho āyasmā lakkhaṇo āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavoca:

sn19.1:1.9.pli: “ko nu kho, āvuso moggallāna, hetu ko paccayo sitassa pātukammāyā”ti?
sn19.1:1.9.eng: “What is the cause, Reverend Moggallāna, what is the reason you smiled?”

sn19.1:1.10.eng: “Reverend Mark, it’s the wrong time for this question.

sn19.1:1.11.pli: Bhagavato maṃ santike etaṃ pañhaṃ pucchā”ti.
sn19.1:1.11.eng: Ask me when we’re in the Buddha’s presence.”

sn19.1:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca lakkhaṇo āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno rājagahe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā lakkhaṇo āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavoca:
sn19.1:2.1.eng: Then Mark and Mahāmoggallāna wandered for alms in Rājagaha. After the meal, on their return from almsround, they went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. Mark said to Mahāmoggallāna:

sn19.1:2.2.pli: “idhāyasmā mahāmoggallāno gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto aññatarasmiṃ padese sitaṃ pātvākāsi.
sn19.1:2.2.eng: “Just now, as Mahāmoggallāna was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain he smiled at a certain spot.

sn19.1:2.3.pli: Ko nu kho, āvuso moggallāna, hetu ko paccayo sitassa pātukammāyā”ti?
sn19.1:2.3.eng: What is the cause, Reverend Moggallāna, what is the reason you smiled?”

sn19.1:3.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantiṃ.
sn19.1:3.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a skeleton flying through the air.

sn19.1:3.2.pli: Tamenaṃ gijjhāpi kākāpi kulalāpi anupatitvā anupatitvā phāsuḷantarikāhi vitudenti vitacchenti virājenti.
sn19.1:3.2.eng: Vultures, crows, and hawks kept chasing it, pecking, clawing, and stabbing it in the ribs
sn19.1:3.2.comm: The verbs here are uncertain and readings vary considerably. See MN 54:16.1, and compare Rig Veda 6.46.14 where horse-racers compete “like birds over raw flesh”.

sn19.1:3.6.eng: That there can be such a sentient being,

sn19.1:3.7.comm: Here yakkha is used as a generic term for “spirit”, “entity”.

sn19.1:4.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

sn19.1:4.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are disciples who live full of vision and knowledge,

sn19.1:4.3.pli: ñāṇabhūtā vata, bhikkhave, sāvakā viharanti, yatra hi nāma sāvako evarūpaṃ ñassati vā dakkhati vā sakkhiṃ vā karissati.
sn19.1:4.3.eng: since a disciple knows, sees, and witnesses such a thing.

sn19.1:4.4.pli: Pubbeva me so, bhikkhave, satto diṭṭho ahosi, api cāhaṃ na byākāsiṃ.
sn19.1:4.4.eng: Formerly, I too saw that being, but I did not speak of it.

sn19.1:4.5.pli: Ahañcetaṃ byākareyyaṃ, pare ca me na saddaheyyuṃ.
sn19.1:4.5.eng: For if I had spoken of it others would not have believed me,

sn19.1:4.6.pli: Ye me na saddaheyyuṃ, tesaṃ taṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
sn19.1:4.6.eng: which would be for their lasting harm and suffering.

sn19.1:4.7.pli: Eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe goghātako ahosi.
sn19.1:4.7.eng: That being used to be a cattle butcher right here in Rājagaha.
sn19.1:4.7.comm: As a butcher, he is treated like a piece of meat (MN 54:16.1). The same applies to the next three discourses.

sn19.1:4.8.pli: So tassa kammassa vipākena bahūni vassāni bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni bahūni vassasatasahassāni niraye paccitvā tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesena evarūpaṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ paṭisaṃvedayatī”ti.
sn19.1:4.8.eng: As a result of that deed he burned in hell for many years, many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years. Now he experiences the residual result of that deed in such an incarnation.”

sn19.1:4.9.eng: (Tell all these discourses in full like this.)

sn19.10:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ kumbhaṇḍaṃ purisaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.10:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a man with testicles big as pots flying through the air.
sn19.10:1.1.comm: The “gnomes” (kumbhaṇḍa, Sanskrit kuṣmāṇḍa, “pumpkin-belly”) were a race of lesser deities often depicted as pot-bellied, ugly and misshapen, though reckoned as subjects of the four great kings (DN 20:9.13). Kumbha also means “pot” and aṇḍa “testicle” (MN 56:25.4). Compare the fiendish kumbhamuṣka (“pot-scrotum”) of Atharva Veda 8.6.15, 11.9.17. Perhaps conflated with kuṣumbha, an insect’s venom-sack (Atharva Veda 2.32.6).

sn19.10:1.2.pli: So gacchantopi teva aṇḍe khandhe āropetvā gacchati.
sn19.10:1.2.eng: When he was walking he had to lift his testicles on to his shoulder.
sn19.10:1.2.comm: While the humorously painful imagery here is clear, it is less clear that the literal sense “pot-balls” was meant in general for the kumbhaṇḍa as a deity. Here it is used adjectivally of a man.

sn19.10:1.3.eng: And when he sat down, he sat right on them.

sn19.10:1.4.pli: Tamenaṃ gijjhāpi kākāpi kulalāpi anupatitvā anupatitvā vitacchenti virājenti.
sn19.10:1.4.eng: Vultures, crows, and hawks kept chasing him, pecking and clawing

sn19.10:1.6.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe gāmakūṭako ahosi …pe….
sn19.10:1.6.eng: “That being used to be a corrupt village head right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.10:1.6.comm: A gāmakūṭa is a “village head” , so kūṭa here means “summit” rather than its other sense of “fraud”, though the senses might be conflated. The commentary explains it as “an official who makes judgements”. The suffix -ka in the form here (gāmakūṭaka) must have its belittling sense like muṇḍakā samaṇakā (“shavelings, fake ascetics”). Kauṭilya depicts the grāmakūṭa as acting on the whispers of an informant (Arthaśāstra 4.4.9). Perhaps his testicles are the size of the pots of gold he made through extortion and blackmail.

sn19.10:2.5.pli: Yo ca sibbiyati sūcako hi so,

sn19.11:1.2.eng: At one time near Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove …

sn19.11:1.3.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ purisaṃ gūthakūpe sasīsakaṃ nimuggaṃ …pe…
sn19.11:1.3.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a man sunk over his head in a sewer. …” …

sn19.11:1.4.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe pāradāriko ahosi …pe….
sn19.11:1.4.eng: “That being used to be an adulterer right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.11:1.4.comm: DN 23:9.1 tells how a man who has escaped a sewer and been provided with all sensual pleasures would not return. Thus the sewer is the inverse of the pleasures of the flesh.

sn19.12:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ purisaṃ gūthakūpe nimuggaṃ ubhohi hatthehi gūthaṃ khādantaṃ …pe…
sn19.12:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a man sunk in a sewer, eating dung with both hands. …” …

sn19.12:1.2.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe duṭṭhabrāhmaṇo ahosi.
sn19.12:1.2.eng: “That being used to be a nasty brahmin right here in Rājagaha.
sn19.12:1.2.comm: Brahmins were obsessed with purity of food.

sn19.12:1.3.pli: So kassapassa sammāsambuddhassa pāvacane bhikkhusaṅghaṃ bhattena nimantetvā doṇiyo gūthassa pūrāpetvā etadavoca—
sn19.12:1.3.eng: In the time of the Buddha Kassapa’s dispensation he invited the Saṅgha of mendicants for a meal. He filled a trough with dung and said:
sn19.12:1.3.comm: Doniya (“trough”) is used for such things as a feeding trough for dogs or pigs (MN 93:11.7), or a casket for a corpse (DN 16:6.17.6).

sn19.12:1.4.pli: aho bhonto yāvadatthaṃ bhuñjantu ceva harantu cā’ti …pe….
sn19.12:1.4.eng: ‘My good men, eat as much as you like, and take what’s left.’ …”

sn19.13:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ nicchaviṃ itthiṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantiṃ.
sn19.13:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a flayed woman flying through the air.

sn19.13:1.2.pli: Tamenaṃ gijjhāpi kākāpi kulalāpi anupatitvā anupatitvā vitacchenti virājenti.
sn19.13:1.2.eng: Vultures, crows, and hawks kept chasing her, pecking and clawing

sn19.13:1.4.pli: esā, bhikkhave, itthī imasmiṃyeva rājagahe aticārinī ahosi …pe….
sn19.13:1.4.eng: “That woman used to be an adulteress right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.13:1.4.comm: Contact, or “touch”, is like a flayed cow (SN 12.63:4.2), so the touches she formerly experienced as pleasant are now excruciating.
